title.title: The Correspondence of John Hunt and Joshua Evans

msIdentifier.institution: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

projectDesc.p: The correspondence of Quaker ministers John Hunt and Joshua Evans are stored at the Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College. With the generous support of H. David and Joyce E. Hunt, Library staff scanned and transcribed these letters in 2023 and encoded the text in TEI. The 2023 project also included researching individuals mentioned in the text to create and update records about them in the Social Networks and Archival Context website

div.p:
Although thou art a stranger to me as to the outward, but being favored with the company of thy dear husband in his traveling through our land, my mind hath been drawn into a near sympathy with thee, with desires thou may be preserved in all thy stepping along now in the time of your long separation, which I make no doubt tends at times to the trial of thy faith. But as thou abides in the patience thou will be the fellow sharer of that enjoyment which this world cannot give, neither can it take it away. I have been favored as above with the company of thy dear husband, not only at my house but likewise at diverse meetings in the verge of Newgarden and Cane Creek Quarterly Meetings, which hath been to me truly comfortable, instructive, and satisfactory, and I hope (notwithstanding his singularities and the path in which he is led there is no doubt with me but as he is careful to keep near to that which first engaged him to leave all that is near and dear in this world, he will be enabled to get through, to the lasting peace of his own mind and to the edification of the churches in general. And, dear friend, remember that those formerly that abode
by the stuff had an equal reward with those that went to the battle. May this be thy happy experience in a spiritual sense, is the real desire of
